stream_context.summary: Kaze live-builds and ultimately scraps the first draft of the cardboard-pyramid level. He pivots to a two-story central hub with multiple exits, instant-warp shortcuts, and better camera flow while texturing, vertex-coloring Mario, and discussing project scope, release risks, and personal life.

development_findings.summary: Kaze abandons the original maze and redesigns the pyramid around a two-floor central room with 4-plus exits to improve navigation while keeping a ‘lost temple’ feel.
development_findings.quote: One central room with two stories and four exits… I like that idea.

development_findings.summary: Instant warp points will return players from dead-ends back to the summit so they can re-hunt red coins without re-ascending the whole structure.
development_findings.quote: I want the player to easily be able to get back up here and not have to go the entire way up the pyramid again.

development_findings.summary: Each single path will hold one red coin; double tunnels will hold two, guaranteeing all eight coins are found within the maze.
Severe camera problems in narrow stairs force geometry tweaks and future camera-collision flag work.
development_findings.quote: The only issue I have with here is that the camera a lot of the time is poopy.

development_findings.summary: Level is authored in Blender, exported with Fast64, and will rely on F3D’s built-in culling plus manual splits for performance.
development_findings.quote: Using Blender as a level editor with Fast64 exports all of this to N64 formats.

development_findings.summary: Kaze adds zero-cost vertex colors and shoe highlights to Mario by lerping Cycle1 alpha to black, giving the model a subtle shine.
development_findings.quote: I added vertex colors to him… and the best part is it’s like 100 free of cost.

development_findings.summary: Project status: two main courses remain; main content targeted for completion in 2025, followed by beta testing.
development_findings.quote: We're like on the last two courses… we'll probably finish all the main content in 2025 but there's still beta left.

development_findings.summary: Because the hack is free, the opening course must be ‘absolute peak’ to hook players who have no monetary investment.
Most discarded geometry is labelled ‘unused early concept’ for future reuse rather than deleted outright.
Design optimization plan: use F3D bounding-box culling outside, split interiors, and potentially remove cranes to cut triangles.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expects a Nintendo takedown within about a week of release and is considering a copyright-free trailer strategy.
context_findings.quote: How long do you think this game will be up before Nintendo takes it down… maybe a week is realistic.

context_findings.summary: He believes giving the hack away for free lowers player commitment, making first-level quality critical.
context_findings.quote: If the first level is not good you're not invested; the fact that this game doesn't cost money is really bad news for us.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes extreme frugality—spending as if he still earned $7k/year and even buying a new pan annually instead of washing dishes.
context_findings.quote: I used to make like $7,000 a year and I don't think my life has changed much since then.

context_findings.summary: He views manual dish-washing as wasted time and argues for two dishwashers; a broken pitcher incident sparks playful blame with Zeina.
context_findings.quote: I will never wash a dish by hand… you're wasting your time.

context_findings.summary: Relocated from Germany to Canada and feels better about life there.
context_findings.quote: I'm glad I'm out of there.

context_findings.summary: Defines himself as ‘an android built for making games,’ highlighting singular creative focus.
context_findings.quote: To be honest, I'm just like an Android built for making games.

biobak.summary: Suggests the two-story central-hub idea that replaces the original maze design.
biobak.quote: Yeah, I see what you mean—I like that idea.

biobak.summary: Assures Kaze he will polish textures later, letting Kaze ignore placeholder visuals.
biobak.quote: Biobak said it's gonna move it so I'm not worrying about it for now.

biobak.summary: Provides frequent design feedback and is jokingly recruited to write scripted jokes for Kaze’s videos.

zeina.summary: Household sink-usage dispute leads to broken water pitcher; illustrates personal-professional overlap.
zeina.quote: We're not a hundred percent in agreement over whose fault it is quite yet.

key_stories.title: Pyramid Redesign Pivot
key_stories.summary: Kaze realizes the initial maze is confusing and camera-unfriendly. After chat (and Biobak) feedback, he scraps it in favor of a central two-story hub with instant warps.
key_stories.challenge: Original layout felt tedious, caused camera issues, and forced players to replay long sections for missed coins.
key_stories.process: Mapped flow on paper/paint, discussed exits, red-coin distribution, and instant-warp shortcuts; labelled old geometry ‘unused early concept’.
key_stories.outcome: New, clearer design approved; most geometry reusable; work continues on texturing and path construction.
key_stories.key_quote: Sucks—I did all this, but most of this is reusable, so it's fine, it's fine, it's fine.

key_stories.title: Nintendo Takedown Anxiety
key_stories.summary: Kaze debates how long the hack will survive online and how to mitigate takedown risk.
key_stories.challenge: History shows Nintendo removes his projects; community expects the same.
key_stories.process: Considers uploading a copyright-free trailer and staggered releases to blunt automated strikes.
key_stories.outcome: Accepts risk; forecasts roughly one week of availability but will release anyway.
key_stories.key_quote: I mean, yeah, you knew this was going to happen, but it still sucks.

key_stories.title: Domestic Pitcher Incident
key_stories.summary: A mundane household clash with Zeina humanizes the developer.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze’s water pitcher broke after he left it on a dish-cluttered sink edge.
key_stories.process: Playful blame game over whose fault—Kaze for placement or Zeina for piling dishes.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze now drinks from an oversized glass; anecdote reveals differing work-life habits.
key_stories.key_quote: Do you think it was my fault that it broke or it was Zeina's?
